video.title: Python Speech Recognition Tutorial – Full Course for Beginners
video.description:
Learn how to implement speech recognition in Python by building five projects. You will learn how to use the AssemblyAI API for speech recognition.

💻 Code: https://github.com/AssemblyAI-Examples/python-speech-recognition-course

✏️ Course created by Misra Turp & Patrick Loeber. They post regularly on the AssemblyAI YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/c/AssemblyAI

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (0:01:37) Audio Processing Basics
⌨️ (0:26:37) Speech Recognition in Python
⌨️ (0:52:48) Sentiment Classification 
⌨️ (1:09:58) Podcast Summarization Web App
⌨️ (1:40:21) Real-time Speech Recognition + Voice Assistant

🏗️ This course was made possible through a grant from Pulumi. Learn more about Pulumi: https://www.assemblyai.com/

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Raymond Odero
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 aldo ferretti
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Sean Trautman
topLevelComment.text: Thanks for the time and effort putting together this tutorial video. Was super helpful. We're taking journalism classes and having a rough time finding good/free software to transcribe short audio interviews (microsoft word transcribe has been best option so far). I used the transcribe part of the tutorial and it worked great. I've done a decent amount of python/js coding so the speed of the tutorial was perfect for me. I had not used API functions in python so the introduction to API was perfect. The workflow you use of getting simple functions working, then organizing them in a separate module and building on it worked great. Looking forward to using the sentiment/podcast tools.

replies.author: Gianmarco Ipinze Tutuianu
replies.text:
@Chris Ibe I had to download couple things

Wheels
VS  Buildtools and install de C++
The lastest pip as well

But what helped me was this: pip install pipwin

After that, you should try to install using "pipwin" instead of pip

pipwin install pyAudio

Another possible issue with the pydub:


Check this video to solve that, if after installing the ffmpeg and pydub you can't create the MP3 file

https://youtu.be/22vmzTs5BoE

replies.author: Igor Garcia
replies.text: @Nameless_divine Thanks!!

replies.author: Nameless_divine
replies.text:
solved
in the code->
signal_array = np.frombuffer(signal_wave, dtype=np.int16)
change this to
signal_array = np.frombuffer(signal_wave, dtype=np.int32)
the int16 ->int32

topLevelComment.author: asksearchknock
topLevelComment.text: I do love this channel and your awesome videos - but it is a little misleading to say speech recognition in python when it’s really just consuming a third party api? Python can do so much really cool stuff locally and using hosted services to do most of the work is not really programming but consuming… would love to see it if you were to cover how to train a model to do this locally or even using a gpu enabled colab - it’s pretty easy and means more people will know the “how” rather than relying on third party tools they don’t understand.

replies.author: Carl
replies.text: Once you learn C++ and/or Java well, any modern language will be easy to pick up despite some syntactical sugar

replies.author: Rayyan Amir
replies.text: No matter what programming language it is, the most important thing is your logic building skills in programming. Programming languages come and go, and can also be learnt in few days. Don't focus much on learning more than one programming language

replies.author: NSA NSA
replies.text: The important question is what do you want to achieve? What’s your goal in programming? Is it web dev, data science etc.? Answering that would be very useful to you as a student to learn efficiently. Don’t run after “cool stuff” online. Find something that you really interested in, and do those type of projects. For example if you genuinely wanna do AI & speech recognition, it’s better if you stick with C lang and learn algorithms deeply, using those public APIs to do a speech recognition is a BS, you can’t call yourself an expert until you develop such an algorithm yourself( at least simple one, or an attempt). I did myself this type of mistake during my uni time, tried all cool tech and didn’t learn much from it. To cut to the chase, find what you like in programming and be laser focused on that.
